author: Grimms
text: An aged count once lived in Switzerland, who had an only son, but he was stupid, and could learn nothing.

author: Grimms
text: Then said the father: "Hark you, my son, try as I will I can get nothing into your head.

author: Grimms
text: You must go from hence, I will give you into the care of a celebrated master, who shall see what he can do with you."

author: Grimms
text: The youth was sent into a strange town, and remained a whole year with the master.

author: Grimms
text: At the end of this time, he came home again, and his father asked: "Now, my son, what have you learnt?"

author: Grimms
text: "Father, I have learnt what the dogs say when they bark."

author: Grimms
text: "Lord have mercy on us!" cried the father; "is that all you have learnt?

author: Grimms
text: I will send you into another town, to another master."

author: Grimms
text: The youth was taken thither, and stayed a year with this master likewise.

author: Grimms
text: When he came back the father again asked: "My son, what have you learnt?"

author: Grimms
text: He answered: "Father, I have learnt what the birds say."

author: Grimms
text: Then the father fell into a rage and said: "Oh, you lost man, you have spent the precious time and learnt nothing; are you not ashamed to appear before my eyes?

author: Grimms
text: I will send you to a third master, but if you learn nothing this time also, I will no longer be your father."

author: Grimms
text: The youth remained a whole year with the third master also, and when he came home again, and his father inquired: "My son, what have you learnt?" he answered: "Dear father, I have this year learnt what the frogs croak."

author: Grimms
text: Then the father fell into the most furious anger, sprang up, called his people thither, and said: "This man is no longer my son, I drive him forth, and command you to take him out into the forest, and kill him."

author: Grimms
text: They took him forth, but when they should have killed him, they could not do it for pity, and let him go, and they cut the eyes and tongue out of a deer that they might carry them to the old man as a token.

author: Grimms
text: The youth wandered on, and after some time came to a fortress where he begged for a night"s lodging.

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," said the lord of the castle, "if you will pass the night down there in the old tower, go thither; but I warn you, it is at the peril of your life, for it is full of wild dogs, which bark and howl without stopping, and at certain hours a man has to be given to them, whom they at once devour."

author: Grimms
text: The whole district was in sorrow and dismay because of them, and yet no one could do anything to stop this.

author: Grimms
text: The youth, however, was without fear, and said: "Just let me go down to the barking dogs, and give me something that I can throw to them; they will do nothing to harm me."

author: Grimms
text: As he himself would have it so, they gave him some food for the wild animals, and led him down to the tower.

author: Grimms
text: When he went inside, the dogs did not bark at him, but wagged their tails quite amicably around him, ate what he set before them, and did not hurt one hair of his head.

author: Grimms
text: Next morning, to the astonishment of everyone, he came out again safe and unharmed, and said to the lord of the castle: "The dogs have revealed to me, in their own language, why they dwell there, and bring evil on the land.

author: Grimms
text: They are bewitched, and are obliged to watch over a great treasure which is below in the tower, and they can have no rest until it is taken away, and I have likewise learnt, from their discourse, how that is to be done."

author: Grimms
text: Then all who heard this rejoiced, and the lord of the castle said he would adopt him as a son if he accomplished it successfully.

author: Grimms
text: He went down again, and as he knew what he had to do, he did it thoroughly, and brought a chest full of gold out with him.

author: Grimms
text: The howling of the wild dogs was henceforth heard no more; they had disappeared, and the country was freed from the trouble.

author: Grimms
text: After some time he took it in his head that he would travel to Rome.

author: Grimms
text: On the way he passed by a marsh, in which a number of frogs were sitting croaking.

author: Grimms
text: He listened to them, and when he became aware of what they were saying, he grew very thoughtful and sad.

author: Grimms
text: At last he arrived in Rome, where the Pope had just died, and there was great doubt among the cardinals as to whom they should appoint as his successor.

author: Grimms
text: They at length agreed that the person should be chosen as pope who should be distinguished by some divine and miraculous token.

author: Grimms
text: And just as that was decided on, the young count entered into the church, and suddenly two snow-white doves flew on his shoulders and remained sitting there.

author: Grimms
text: The ecclesiastics recognized therein the token from above, and asked him on the spot if he would be pope.

author: Grimms
text: He was undecided, and knew not if he were worthy of this, but the doves counselled him to do it, and at length he said yes.

author: Grimms
text: Then was he anointed and consecrated, and thus was fulfilled what he had heard from the frogs on his way, which had so affected him, that he was to be his Holiness the Pope.

author: Grimms
text: Then he had to sing a mass, and did not know one word of it, but the two doves sat continually on his shoulders, and said it all in his ear.
